name: 2-propenoic acid, 3- 3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl -
Reason: The target compound is a derivative of 2-propenoic acid (acrylic acid) with a 3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl group attached to the alpha carbon. The base structure of acrylic acid has a melting point of around 13°C. The presence of the phenyl ring would normally increase the melting point due to increased pi-pi interaction and planarity, giving a positive increment. For a phenyl group, we might typically assign an increment of around +40°C. The trifluoromethyl group is electron-withdrawing and contributes to the rigidity of the structure; it is also bulky and highly electronegative, which tends to further raise the melting point. We might assign an increment of around +50°C for the combined induction and resonance effects it introduces. The acrylic acid double bond itself has less influence on melting point as it may disrupt crystal packing; the effect can be considered near neutral or slightly increasing (+5°C) due to possible additional stabilizing interactions. Cumulatively, we'd predict a melting point higher than the base acrylic acid by about 95°C.

name: 2-propenoic acid, 3- 3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl -
Reason: The target compound is a derivative of 2-propenoic acid (acrylic acid) with a 3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl group attached to the alpha carbon. The base structure of acrylic acid has a melting point of around 13°C. The addition of the phenyl group contributes to the rigidity of the molecule and increases van der Waals interactions, which would normally increase the melting point; an estimated increment due to the phenyl group could be around +50°C due to these interactions. The trifluoromethyl group is strongly electron-withdrawing and adds further rigidity as well as contributing to dipole-dipole interactions given its electronegativity, which we could estimate as another +60°C. The double bond in the acrylic portion may slightly disrupt crystal packing, but it can also participate in stabilizing interactions; thus, its influence on the melting point can be considered slightly positive, possibly around +5°C. When considering the cumulative effect of these functional groups, the increment added to the base melting point of acrylic acid would be approximately 115°C.
